text: My name's Natalie Nicholles and I'm the executive director
of an NGO called The Capitals Coalition.
The Capitals Coalition is a global collaboration
that's helping trying to update the economic system
so that all forms of capital, are valued
and are sustained.
The Coalition itself

is about 460 organizations at the core.
A lot of our work is about convening
and bringing these different actors from across business,
finance, policy, standards setter, academia
together in a room to try to understand how we can advance
these big challenges that we have in our system.

We all believe in the same thing,
that
the decisions we make in our economy should be based

not on one capital, which is financial,
but on four capitals,
natural capital, nature,

social capital, society,
human capital,
people and financial capital.
Why is it so important to have

all of these different actors
in the room together?
Because we are never going to solve climate change,
biodiversity loss or inequality.
These really wicked problems, just by one entity alone.
And we're talking about the scale of climate change,
which affects everybody.
The pace of biodiversity loss, which affects our ability
to deal with climate change and rising inequality.
Our economic system doesn't value what matters.
We haven't been working for the past 70 years with a system
that values nature and people.
And the predominant metric, which is GDP,

which was developed in the 1930s
following the Great Depression,
then grew in popularity after the Second World War,
was brilliant for that time, right?
If we had more fuel and food and commodities
that equated with prosperity.
And we had an abundance of nature at the time.
Now, those things are not equating with prosperity,
but because our economic systems don't value them,
then we don't know how to address some of these challenges.
And that's why we need policymakers and investors
and companies in the room
to help solve the problem with civil society.

We have to transition to a net zero world
that is socially equitable
and doesn't mash up our nature and our natural resources.
So essentially, are you saying that

Western society
has been getting capitalism wrong?
I wouldn't say Western society has got capitalism wrong.
We used GDP when we needed to
to understand how successful our economies were going to be.
We had to rebuild our economies after the Second World War.
The economy is a human construct.
All of every decision we make shapes the economy.

The economy is going to change
because our decisions will change.
So it's not that capitalism was wrong.

It's that we are just evolving
towards a
different understanding of value
and making sure that we value what matters
and that that is at the center of how we run our companies.
Can you give us a few examples of changes that are happening
that are giving you hope?
We have some real leaders who have been innovating
and they've been using what we would call capitalist
accounting, bringing these externalities

into their decision
making processes,
using integrated profit and loss accounts
or other kind or balance sheet approaches

to help to make real decisions
about
the extent to which they are paying

living wages in their supply chains
or their exposure to water,
and how they're going to manage those risks
in order to have resilient businesses in the future.

If you're a drinks company,
water is a really big resource for you
but if that is being depleted
and you are part of that depletion,
thenyou're not going to have a business model in the future.
So we are seeing some real progressive thinking.
How can business, civil society
and regulators work better together to drive more consistent
and transparent disclosure?
I think the real question about disclosure
is about whether or not itâ€™s useful for decision making.
There is obviously some fantastic progress that's been made

on the sustainability disclosure side,
and that is continuing.

But there is also pushback
about the volume of that disclosure
and its usability for decision making, right?
The extent to which a company can understand its risk
and reallocate capital or transform its business model.
The issue is less about transparency, but
the issue is more can we make sure that this information

that we don't normally include in our
economic and non-financial models?
Can we trust it?
Can we build confidence in information on impact?
In Europe, we talk a lot about double materiality,
the extent to which companies

have an impact on society,
as well as
systemic risk having an impact on the company.
But that information has to be trusted.
And the capitalist coalition in recent weeks has released
a beta framework for integrated decision making,

which provides the criteria
for
this confidence of information on impact.
Are some companies starting to use it?
They are.
Yes, and we're in a consultation period at the moment,
and we have had interest from companies who want to pilot that.
Exactly
to have the confidence in this information on impact.
But in terms of your question, I'd go back to the

top
tip is actually around capacity building.
There is a dearth of knowledge
about sustainability and how the science plays into business models

and how the science plays into
how financiers manage their portfolios.
And so there's a whole wave of capacity

building
that needs to take place.

There seem to be more conversations
about nature and biodiversity.
Even in the last year.
Tell us what is driving that conversation right now.
Nature is in vogue, and it's about time.
There's been decades worth of work done on this.
And as the systemic nature of climate change and inequality
grow, the recognition that we can't solve those
without managing how we deal with nature
will also grow. I think the big challenge with it is that
it is always there in the background
and it can be easily eclipsed by other political challenges.

What do you think it's going to take
to get the financial industry on board
in a bigger way?
It sounds a bit cliche, but it's going to take courage.
It's going to take real courageous leadership and vision.

And as with any parts of our history
as humans,
we've always seen pockets of that.
We see pockets of it now within the financial

services
and within the finance industry.
We need capital to flow to where it's needed most.
I mean, the policy to create an enabling environment for that.
And we need to encourage business innovation
to come up with the solutions that are going to help us in the future.
